awd_titl_txt: Chemomechanics of Thin Film Detachment in Liquid-Assisted Transfer Printing
awd_abstract_narration:
Transfer printing is a technique of assembling layered structures in which a thin film or layers of thin films processed on a source substrate are picked and released onto a target substrate. This operation is performed successively until the desired layered structure is formed. This process is widely used in the fabrication of micro- to nano-scale thin film based devices, especially in the production of flexible electronics.  In current practice, the technique relies heavily on trial and error, which results in low yields. This is particularly true for the transfer of thin films with multiple layers or discrete structures, where damage and residual contamination are quite common. This award will focus on the fundamental study of detachment mechanics of thin film-substrate systems in a liquid environment. The outcome of this research will impact the design and execution of transfer printing process through development of simple steps and relationships for high, yet efficient, throughput. This research is an interdisciplinary study involving chemo-mechanics, materials science and manufacturing. Graduate and undergraduate students will be exposed to and trained on a broad scope of education and skills, respectively. Undergraduate students form underrepresented groups will be actively recruited and a university program will be leveraged to perform K-12 outreach. 

Transfer printing is emerging as a competitive technique in the delivery and assembly of thin films in manufacturing. Its working efficiency is inherently underpinned by the detachment mechanics of thin films from substrates. The liquid-assisted transfer printing technique could promote both yield and quality of the detachment of thin films and involves a synergistic interplay of external mechanical loading and chemical reactions at the solid-liquid interface. The project will conduct a comprehensive study of liquid-assisted interfacial detachment in film-substrate systems, where the presence of liquid water will react with interfacial materials, leading to a controllable and selective detachment of thin film layers. The outcome of this study will be two-fold: 1) a comprehensive chemomechanics theory of liquid-driven detachment mechanics, and 2) a hybrid computational modeling framework that bridges solid-liquid atomistic interactions (mechanism) and continuum phenomena of film detachment (structural function) with validation from experimental testing and theory. The research will impact the transfer printing fabrication technique by providing scientific and technological means to achieving efficient, quantitative throughput.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: RECTOR & VISITORS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF VIRGINIA

por.por_cntn:
Mechanical transfer is a technology of picking up a material from a donor substrate and releasing it onto a receiver substrate and is the foundation in the manufacturing of an entire class of wearable technologies, in particular, film-based flexible electronics and devices. Transfer printing of film with a high yield and precision control is the key. With the completion of this project, we developed a novel transfer printing in a liquid environment that are enabled by interfacial delimitations with the coupling of solid-solid and solid-liquid interactions and proposed the underlying fundamental mechanics theories and computational models along with the experimental conductions. We proposed a liquid-assisted, etching-free transfer printing technique in a liquid environment, and developed a theory framework to predict the peel-off force by incorporating surface wettability of both 2D materials and substrates, and surface tension of liquid into the classic peeling theory. The theoretical predictions were well confirmed with full scale molecular dynamics simulations on a broad variety of substrate materials with various surface wettability. When chemical bonding is formed between film and substrate. We proposed a chemomechanics theory to study the interfacial delamination, where chemical reaction is led by hydrolysis. In the theoretical development of this chemomechanics theory, kinetic chemical reaction theory was proposed to obtain the rate dependent interfacial energy release rate and was also incorporated into the interface fracture process of thin film and substrate. To validate the proposed chemomechanics theory, we developed an atomistic-continuum modeling framework to simulate and predict the entire liquid-assisted peeling process at the macroscale. Remarkable agreement between theory and computation was obtained, and both them also agreed with experimental data. To guide practical applications of the proposed theory, transfer printing of silicon ribbons, nanomembranes, Ag nanowire, and 3D nanopillars on silicon substrate were performed. Besides, their quality of transferred films was characterized and compared with those obtained by conventional transfer printing in drying air. Further, to remove the uncertainty led by the applied external mechanical force during the transfer printing and improve the controlling accuracy, we proposed the transfer printing technology under an electrical field, where the voltage is used to control the interfacial delamination without the need of external mechanical force and is underpinned by the electro-chemo-mechanical interfacial delamination. We established a comprehensive electro-chemo-mechanics theoretical framework of film detachment from various electrode substrates in an electrolyte solution environment and also predicted the delamination rate and strain distribution in film. In parallel, we developed a finite element model to simulate the interfacial delamination process between film and electrode substrates by implementing the electro-chemo-mechanics models. In addition, to decouple the effect of chemical reaction and mechanical deformation in the transfer printing of films, we created a new transfer printing technique where a film was fabricated on the surface of non-corrosive liquid and then transferred onto a solid substrate. We developed comprehensive theoretical models and performed extensive experiments and simulations on a broad material diversity of film and liquid, surface wetting property and geometric patterns of soft films and receiver substrates and proved the feasibility of this novel transfer printing technology. These results have led to 10 peer- reviewed journal publications including 2 PNAS and 2 IJSS.

The PI and support PhD students have reported the results through ASME-IMCE conferences, SES meeting, TMS meeting, and several department seminars. One PhD has finished the PhD degree and now is a post-doc at the University of Pennsylvania. The other PhD student is expected to graduate in 2023 Spring. PhD students have been awarded Student Poster Travel Award for several times, the most informative poster by 2021 ASME-IMECE, and Haythornthwaite Foundation Student Travel Award (only 10 awardee in 2020). The PI was invited to write one journal perspective summarizing the progress in this field of relevance to this project and has also awarded 2020 ASME Sia Nemat-Nasser Early Career Award.

The research results of relevance were lectured in graduate-level class MAE 6070 The theory of Elasticity, and were also incorporated into a newly developed undergraduate student course: Mechanical Design and Manufacturing in Wearable Electronics (MAE4610), offered course by the PI.


Last Modified: 09/04/2022
Modified by: Baoxing Xu
